content.content: Note: This Signal Request has been amended to include an actionable outcome from the vote.   TLDR  Restart Burn Immediately  Burn at a reduced rate until we develop something better.   Restore Revenue Distribution Narrative  Burn until we have a concrete system to replace it.   Retain Investors Retain our Community & Talent   Overview In my opinion, putting aside my own personal shituation, shutting off the burn at a market cycle bottom was arguably one of the worst decisions we have made as a community to date. I will admit that are benefits to operating on a model that prioritizes reinvesting into growth during early stages rather than distributing revenue. It works for Amazon, and it works for many others as well. It may even work for us as well. Unfortunately, in practice, what we’ve done is turn off the only revenue distribution model we had… at a market cycle bottom. I know it was not perfect. It was inefficient, gameable, and didn’t perceptibly return value to MKR holders. Still imperfect as it was, people liked it. I liked it, and so did many others. As it stands, we have no concrete plan in place to distribute revenue. We removed what we had but are yet to replace it with anything new. Our community members and long-term investors are dropping out like flies. Some from 2018 PTSD, others have just lost faith in our governance community’s ability to deliver. We still have revenue, though! It may be less than before, but that’s expected during a period of market contraction and a general reduction in appetite to borrow and take on risk.  This is temporary!  No market can maintain consistent negative perp funding indefinitely. A majority of market players taking one side of a position for pushing six months now are inevitably going to get rekt. It’s rare that everyone is right.  At some point there will be a new funding cycle. People will get excited and borrow again. I’m not concerned about our temporary dip in revenue. The burn is what retained many of our investors for years. Even through Black Thursday, one of the most challenging times we had to face as a community, we held through it. Yes, we did mint, and MKR suffered but has recovered since. As it stands, though, we still have the mint risk but no burn to counterbalance it. This puts many of our holders into a very tricky state of having to weigh underwriting huge codified downside risk with no clear promise of upside. It becomes very easy to justify classifying MKR as an overly risk-on asset during liquidity crunches. Dumping during times of uncertainty is a no-brainer. As each individual dumps, we increasingly expose ourselves to a governance attack. At this point, the illiquidity of MKR may be the only thing saving us from a nefarious actor buying up enough MKR to control the system. None of us want to see this. Given how essential Maker and DAI are to this space and the world in general, it would be disastrous to allow ourselves to capitulate into handing over control of this protocol to bad actors. It’s not just about “wen moon?” or "number go up blz! Ya, I’d like that… since I’m super rekt right now… “can dev do something?” I wish… but that’s not important. MakerDAO is genuinely in a place to change the world for the better. We deliver untold value and self-sovereignty to people in parts of the world that have nowhere else to turn to but DAI. Do any of us really expect them to use UST or USDT? They want… no… they NEED DAI. We need to retain our community at all costs to succeed. Complacency right now will be the end of us.   Restart the Burn So, in part… I understand why we shut off the burn. We had extreme slippage, and it appeared like we were just wasting money. The slippage was terrible, yes. It’s a consequence of our community kicking the can down the road about implementing any sort of marketing-making scheme… but it is what it is for now. If we burn, it will be with slippage. The other argument for not burning was that we need to save DAI in the treasury to accumulate for a true Black Swan. Maybe?? It just so happened that as that sentiment creeped in and we decided to pause Burning, it was at the exact bottom (so far, knock on wood) for crypto. Yes, I know Macro fell more later on. Anyway, we got all flustered and cash happy at arguably the worst time to hoard cash. Although it may seem like everything is dumping, as it stands, BTC and ETH are just holding a steady uptrend. (Yes, I know it looks ready to go to zero any day now… but how else does a market shake everyone out?) Basically, we started hoarding cash when it was time to deploy. As the market continues to appear worse and worse, we continue to hoard. Regrettably, no amount of hoarding will protect us from a Black Swan if one is coming. The SB will be drained instantly, MKR will be minted… and nice knowing all of you! At these prices, though, do we REALLY lack so much faith in our project that we wouldn’t buyback and burn when it’s undervalued by at least two orders? Finally, IMO, all price action below $2,000 MKR can be directly attributed to removing the burn.  Poll Detials We can restart the burn with a reduced lid parameter to mitigate many of the inefficiencies we faced on our last auction. We will burn at a slower rate but maintain our original revenue distribution model until we enter a new funding cycle and/or once a new tokenomics model is developed, has community approval, and is ready to be implemented. Note: The Risk Core Unit Team suggests reducing the hump to $54M, so I will be including that value for this Signal Request.     Lower the SB? | Restart the Burn?     Yes: Reduce hunp to $54M.  No: Take no action at this time. Abstain     0 voters     This poll will run until May 14th. 2022-05-02T00:00:00Z→2022-05-14T11:11:00Z If successful, an on-chain vote will be held to confirm the changes.  Note: This poll assumes @ultraschuppi’s Signal Request to change the lid Parameter on the Rate Limiter passes successfully. I will issue a second Signal Request to change the ‘lid’ parameter if it does not. An over;y aggressive burn will be inefficient.   Next Steps  If we opt to restart the burn, we should focus on fully developing a new tokenomics and revenue distribution model complete and ready to go for a seamless transition from one paradigm to the next. Everyone should put a post-it on their screen or tattoo it onto their forehead:  "Never again switch up a narrative at a market cycle bottom." It’s great to experiment with new ideas, but save that for the euphoric stage of the market. There’s a lot more forgiveness in those times.      Burning & Aggressive Growth | A Potential Marriage We can design a very efficient burn schedule based on sentiment counter trading if we decide to retain a burn model down the road. It’s not very complicated and allows both strategies to coexist. The basic premise is to accumulate DAI for Aggressive Growth during manic market phases and burn during fear and capitulation phases. These phases are reasonably easy to identify and don’t require much data. If we opt to retain any kind of burn model, I would be happy to contribute here.  A Sample Burn Schedule  4511×2516 749 KB  The chart above shows market sentiment data from 2020 to the present.  The neon dots below change colors to indicate a shift in market sentiment.  The colors correspond to periods across the spectrum of the overall market sentiment. During Manic Phases, we should pause burning and accumulate for Aggressive Growth. During capitulation and fear phases, we should ramp up the burn.    Pink & Light Pink: Mania and Euphoria | Immediately cease burning. Accumulate into the treasury.  Orange & White: Neutral | Light burn. Predominantly accumulate into the treasury.  Blue: Fear | Crank the Burn  Green: Panic and Capitulation | Initiate Nitro Burn  Red: Extreme Capitulation | Activate Nitro Burn on Steroids     Note: - Red is the maximum level this indicator can theoretically output. - However, Red appears so infrequently that waiting for it is not practical.     Final Thoughts I know the burn model we had wasn’t perfect, but I hope I’m not talking to a wall here. I want to see Maker thrive. If there’s something so much better we can implement right now, then sure… but we’re notorious for moving slow. Aggravating? of course… but it’s how we’ve built our reputation. Every change and upgrade is checked twelve times before being implemented. We build to last, but let’s not bleed our talent and community.  Words of Wisdom  850×400 41.7 KB  Whatever your view on the market is… no matter your conviction, remember to pause and look around. Can you find anyone that disagrees with you?? If the answer is no, ask yourself… are you really in the minority? Maybe I’m the fool here, and everyone else is right.   Archived: Signal Request V1

content.content: To kick off the discussion on this thread, I will reiterate a few things:  I am not pro-burn indefinitely. Buyback & Make is likely a superior model, and I would wholeheartedly support it.  Regrettably, it is not live yet. Once it is ready for deployment, I would fully support a shift to that model over pure burning.   I would like to work with Wintermute, as I have built a relationship with them and believe they are good actors. I would also like to see @MakerMan’s ideas implemented alongside for on-chain liquidity solutions that our protocol can directly earn revenue on. As it stands, the only tool that we have ready on hand to deploy is the burner. Everything else, no matter how much better it may be, is nowhere near to being ready for deployment. We cannot afford to lose any more of our community members who feel disenfranchised as they capitulate and abandon Maker.  The losses from this Brain Drain are incalculable and outweigh every other argument that favors delaying taking action until better tools are developed.   If we lose our community, we lose MakerDAO.

content.content: I voted No on this Signal Request. Aggressive Growth and organic DAI demand are the way forward. While I understand the theoretical risk of hostile takeovers and disgruntled MKR holders, I’ve come to the conclusion that reinstating MKR burn with the parameters outlined is not a good business decision. When I think about a company increasing stock buybacks as revenue goes down… It just doesn’t seem right. I know this analogy is a bit of a stretch, but the basic thinking behind it holds. Growing Maker means to grow organic DAI demand. Burning MKR has no effect on that. Maker is leading innovation in RWF and D3M, and there are some other low-hanging fruits it could reasonably pick to increase DAI demand. Many of those have been outlined in the comments here. From lending more aggressively to startup DAOs to lobbying for DAI at payment providers. Also, MakerMan has a good point here:    [Signal Request] Restart The Burn  [V1] xxx [Canceled] [Refer to updated V2, link below]   DeFI now offers DAOs much better tools to invest capital that earns return and satisfies DAO goals, the flapper mechanic is completely outdated and a waste of resources.   I’m one of the people in this conversation with little Maker experience, but for me, it all doesn’t add up. If there’s one thing I learned in my life and my career it is this: Never act from desperation. It only leads to more pain. We need to act from a clear vision and from inspiration about what MakerDAO will be in 10 years. How will it look if we win?

We removed what we had but are yet to replace it with anything new.   Even if this signal does not pass, it seems important to address these valid concerns. Maybe a new system for distributing part of the protocol’s profits to tokenholders could be tied to reaching a certain target level on the Surplus Buffer (say, 250m). This could provide more certainty (essentially a new social contract) for community members that share the concerns above.

content.content: I voted No - it’s unfortunate to backpedal and see this topic reopened soon after the previous vote passed. I’ll restate my position that although burning did bring in community members, it’s not an effective way to grow value to Maker and its holders. I understand that everyone, myself included, would like the value of MKR to appreciate. However, burning acts as a bandage. The real solution relies on growth activities through a beefed-up SB to increase revenue and the protocol’s fundamental value. It won’t result in overnight appreciation, but developing the core value props will get us there. As for revenue distribution, there are some exciting conversations ongoing for new, innovative DAO governance and token models. These ideas go above and beyond the burning mechanism to return value to the community. I’m looking forward to seeing those ideas develop for the future of the DAO. content.content: If there is no mechanism for Maker to distribute returns to holders, then MKR is worthless; a circular argument unto itself. If the value proposition is now solely that it buys you a vote in the governance process, then how does that vote actually benefit the holder? If they vote diligently, and prudently, and intelligently, the platform can be a success, and even generate revenue - but then what? We can talk about “aggressive growth” or “deploying the reserves” etc. etc., but all that must be a means to some end that returns value to the holders. Otherwise holding Maker is nothing but downside, since it’s the collateral of last resort. You can’t blame todays holders for not trusting governance that one day they will be made whole. To an outsider, it looks very much like governance has been reactionary / improvised on the fly ever since the DAO transition. I consider that the burn was the mechanism that wasn’t meant to be turned on and off at will. Governance has taken something beautiful in its simplicity and started playing “Central Bank” with it - a role which I can’t help but feel it is ill equipped to perform.

content.content: Well, I’m not going to say I understand all the factors at work but I’ll tell you my thoughts.  Ethereum hit a peak in May, crashed, and then ran back up at a slower pace from July to September.  What was unfortunate was that Ethereum ran back up to an even higher place in November but MKR did not participate in that rally at all.  My conjecture is that the expanding CU budgets being proposed made a big impact in there and even though the underlying revenue did rise with eth price, there was negativity with rising expenses and the ending of the mkr burn. Anyway, it’s all good if those investments bear fruit.  Theoretically the CU expenditures are supposed to eventually produce growth.  But we don’t see it yet so some investors are probably losing trust that CU investments are actually bearing fruit.  Maybe it will bear fruit but it seems like it’s going to take awhile.  The promise of RWA is that we can finally grow without being so tied to the crypto markets.  If you see revenues start growing from non-crypto collateral, I think MKR price will start to become more disconnected from the broader crypto market.  But crypto loans basically make up all of our revenue right now so it will be awhile before that actually happens. If you are a long term investor, you really have to remind yourself that the protocol is still profitable so if you believe in the vision, you can give it time to bear fruit.  There still isn’t too much in terms of competition for crypto bridging into the real world so it’s not clear how all this will end up.  There are a lot of risks that give us some urgency though.  There’s a lot more competition on the crypto side so if MKR loses market share on its bread and butter crypto collateral, revenue will go down.  Or if the fed interest rate actions start affecting DAI demand, and you’re forced to defend the peg by increasing the DSR, spending will go up.  And if we ever start to be unprofitable without clear revenue growth…well, look out below.
